div.l: But as sauh / a white thyng in hir eye
And whan she gan / this white thyng espye
She wende the clerk / hadde wered a volupere
And with the staf / she drouh ay neer ⁊and neer
And wende haue hit / this Alayn at the fulle
And smot / the millere / on the piled skulle
That doıı̄un he goth / and cryed herawe I dye
Thes clerkes beet hym wel / ⁊and let hym lye
And greythen hem / and took ther hors a noon
And eek her mele / and on her weye they goon
And at the mille dore / eek they took ther cake
Of half a busshel flour / wol wel I bake
Thus is the proude millere / wel I bete
And hath I lost / the gryndyng of his whete
And payde for the soupeer / euerydel
Of Alayn ⁊and of Iohn / that beete hym wel
His wyf is swived / ⁊and his douhtir als
Lo what is a millere / to be fals
And therto this proverbe / is seid ful soth
Hym dar nat weene wel / that euyl doth
A gilour shal hym silf / giled be
And god that sit / in his mageste
Save aƚƚlle this companye grete and smale
Thus have I quyt / the millere in my tale

l.hi: Here bigynneth the ꝓprolog͗e of the cookis tale

div.l: The cook of london̄ / with the Reeve spak
For Ioye hym thouhte / he clawed hym on the bak
Ha ha he seyde / for crystes passioıı̄un
The millere hath / a sharp conclusioıı̄un
Vpon his Argument / of herbergage
Wel seyde Salamon / in his langage
Ne bryng nat eủery man / to thyn hous
To ben herberwed / for it is perlous
Wel auhte a man / avised for to be
Whom that he brouhte / in to his privite
I pray to god / so yeue me sorwe ⁊and care
